Key Match Events: Steven Kwan drilled opener Tyler Holton’s second pitch off the right-field wall for a leadoff double
José Ramírez chopped a hard ground ball that third baseman Zack McKinstry couldn’t handle, and it trickled into the left-field corner
Lane Thomas hit a walk-off grand slam in the ninth inning
Pre-Game Insights: Cleveland had earned a coveted first-round bye, bypassing the harrowing wild-card round
Detroit had taken down the Astros on the road
Detroit's pitching strategy that rarely faltered during a remarkable run to the postseason and past the Astros backfired in spectacular fashion
Cleveland's five-run blitz in the first inning tied the MLB record for runs scored to start a postseason game before recording an out
Manager Stephen Vogt had the luxury of being ultra-aggressive with his bullpen, even with a substantial lead
Post-Match Reflections: The way we looked at it was, we're going to get five days of rest. We get to recover. We get to turn off for a few days. And we worked them hard. To the players' credit, they put a ton of effort into our workouts. They got competitive with each other in some simulated games, and it showed. We came out ready to swing the bat, and we looked like we didn't take five days off.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Detroit's manager AJ Hinch explained his decision to go to Reese Olson in that spot
Cleveland's five-run blitz in the first inning was the most runs scored to start a postseason game before recording an out, joining last year's D-backs in Game 1 of the NLDS against the Dodgers

Cleveland's five-run blitz in the first inning was nearly unprecedented offensive display occurring in front of a packed home crowd of 33,548 eager to explode before the Guardians even picked up a bat
